appreciable.meaning_1: adjective: large enough to be noticed (usu. refers to an amount)
appreciable.sentence_1: There is an appreciable difference between those who say they can get the job done and those who actually get the job done.

impermeable.meaning_1: adjective: does not allow fluids to pass through
impermeable.sentence_1: The sand bags placed on the river formed an impermeable barrier, protecting the town from flooding.

malady.sentence_1: The town was struck by a malady throughout the winter that left most people sick in bed for two weeks.

morose.meaning_1: adjective: ill-tempered and not inclined to talk; gloomy
morose.sentence_1: After Stanley found out he was no longer able to go on vacation with his friends, he sat in his room morosely.

ornate.meaning_1: adjective: marked by elaborate rhetoric and elaborated with decorative details
ornate.sentence_1: The ornate Victorian and Edwardian homes spread throughout San Francisco are my favorite part of the city.

malleable.sentence_2: My little brother is so malleable that I can convince him to sneak cookies from the cupboard for me.
malleable.sentence_1: The clay became malleable and easy to work with after a little water was added.
malleable.meaning_1: adjective: capable of being shaped or bent or drawn out

deter.sentence_2: The government's primary job should involve deterring paths to war, not finding ways to start them.
deter.meaning_2: verb: try to prevent; show opposition to
deter.sentence_1: His mother tried to deter him from joining the army, but he was too intoxicated with the idea of war to listen.
deter.meaning_1: verb: turn away from by persuasion

fledgling.meaning_1:
adjective: young and inexperienced
noun: any new participant in some activity
fledgling.sentence_1: Murray has years of experience in family practice, but he is just a fledgling in surgery.

archaic.meaning_1: adjective: so old as to appear to belong to a different period
archaic.sentence_1: Hoping to sound intelligent, Mary spoke in archaic English that was right out of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice--needless to say, she didn't have many friends.

transitory.meaning_1: adjective: lasting a very short time
transitory.sentence_1: If we lived forever and life was not transitory, do you think we would appreciate life less or more?

discriminate.meaning_1: verb: recognize or perceive the difference
discriminate.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
discriminate.sentence_1: Sarah couldn't discriminate between a good wine and a bad wine, so she avoided wine tastings.

proponent.meaning_1: noun: a person who pleads for a cause or propounds an idea
proponent.sentence_1: Ironically, the leading proponent of Flat-Earth Theory flies all over the world in an effort to win more adherents.

endemic.meaning_1: adjective: native; originating where it is found
endemic.sentence_1: Irish cuisine makes great use of potatoes, but ironically, the potato is not endemic to Ireland.

muted.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
muted.sentence_1: Helen preferred muted earth colors, such as green and brown, to the bright pinks and red her sister liked.

avid.meaning_1: adjective: marked by active interest and enthusiasm
avid.sentence_1: Martin is an avid birdwatcher, often taking long hikes into remote mountains to see some rare eagle.

incessant.meaning_1: adjective: uninterrupted in time and indefinitely long continuing
incessant.sentence_1: I don't mind small children in brief doses, but I think the incessant exposure that their parents have to them would quickly wear me down.

disheartened.meaning_1: adjective: made less hopeful or enthusiastic
disheartened.sentence_1: After the visiting team scored nine times, the home team's fans were disheartened, some leaving the game early.

obdurate.meaning_1: adjective: unable to be persuaded or moved emotionally; stubborn; unyielding.
obdurate.sentence_1: No number of pleas and bribes would get him to change his obdurate attitude.

robust.meaning_1: adjective: sturdy and strong in form, constitution, or construction
robust.sentence_1: Chris preferred bland and mild beers, but Bhavin preferred a beer with more robust flavor.

stolid.meaning_1: adjective: having or revealing little emotion or sensibility; not easily aroused or excited
stolid.sentence_1: Elephants may appear stolid to casual observers, but they actually have passionate emotional lives.

impede.meaning_1: verb: be a hindrance or obstacle to
impede.sentence_1: Since the police sergeant had to train the pair of new hires, progress in his own case was impeded.

thwart.meaning_1: verb: hinder or prevent (the efforts, plans, or desires) of
thwart.sentence_1: I wanted to spend a week in New York this autumn, but the high costs of travel and lodging thwarted my plans.

guffaw.sentence_1: Whenever the jester fell to the ground in mock pain, the king guffawed, exposing his yellow, fang-like teeth.

pithy.meaning_1: adjective: concise and full of meaning
pithy.sentence_1: I enjoy reading the Daodejing for its pithy and insightful prose; it always gives me something to think about.

inclement.sentence_2: Marcus Aurelius, though a fair man, was inclement to Christians during his reign, persecuting them violently.
inclement.meaning_2: adjective: used of persons or behavior; showing no mercy
inclement.sentence_1: After a week of inclement weather, we finally are able to go outside and enjoy the sun.

respite.meaning_1: noun: a pause from doing something (as work)
respite.sentence_1: Every afternoon, the small company has a respite in which workers play foosball or board games.

flounder.sentence_1: Sylvia has excelled at advanced calculus, but ironically, when she has to deal with taxes, she flounders.

ascendancy.meaning_1: noun: the state that exists when one person or group has power over another
ascendancy.sentence_1: The ascendancy of the Carlsbad water polo team is clear—they have a decade of championships behind them.

plodding.sentence_1: Charlie may seem to run at a plodding pace, but he is an ultramarathoner, meaning he runs distances of up to 100 miles, and can run for ten hours at a stretch.

disenfranchise.sentence_1: The U.S. Constitution disenfranchised women until 1920 when they were given the right to vote.

elusive.meaning_1: adjective: difficult to capture or difficult to remember
elusive.sentence_1: Many first time skydivers say that describing the act of falling from the sky is elusive.

patronize.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
patronize.sentence_1: She says she genuinely wanted to help me, but instead she patronized me, constantly pointing out how I was inferior to her.

fete.sentence_1: After World War II, war heroes were feted at first but quickly forgotten.

entice.meaning_1: verb: get someone to do something through (often false or exaggerated) promises
entice.sentence_1: Harold enticed his wife, Maude, to go on a vacation to Hawaii, with promises of luaus on the beach and all-you-can-eat seafood buffets.

autonomously.meaning_1: adverb: Acting independently; self-governing (of a country)
autonomously.sentence_1: Many of the factory workers are worried about being replaced by machines and computers that will work completely autonomously.

moot.meaning_1: adjective: open to argument or debate; undecidable in a meaningless or irrelevant way
moot.sentence_1: Since the Board just terminated Steve as the CEO, what the finance committee might have thought of his proposed marketing plan for next year is now a moot point.

ingenuity.meaning_1: noun: the power of creative imagination
ingenuity.sentence_1: Daedalus was famous for his ingenuity; he was able to fashion his son Icarus with a pair of wings, using wax to hold them together.

dearth.sentence_1: I am surprised by the dearth of fast food chains; this is America and I assumed they were on every street.

meander.sentence_1: A casual observer might have thought that Peter was meandering through the city, but that day he was actually seeking out those places where he and his long lost love had once visited.

boon.sentence_2: He was a boon companion to many, and will be sadly missed.
boon.sentence_1: Modern technology has been a boon to the travel industry.

degrade.meaning_1: verb: reduce in worth or character, usually verbally
degrade.sentence_1: Jesse had mockingly pointed out all of Nancy's faults in front of their friends, publicly degrading the poor girl.

resolve.meaning_1: verb: reach a conclusion after a discussion or deliberation
resolve.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
resolve.sentence_1: After much thought, Ted resolved not to travel abroad this summer because he didn't have much money in his bank account.

jocular.meaning_1: adjective: characterized by jokes and good humor
jocular.sentence_1: My uncle was always in a jocular mood at family gatherings, messing up people's hair and telling knock-knock jokes to anyone who would listen.

snide.meaning_1: adjective: expressive of contempt; derogatory or mocking in an indirect way
snide.sentence_1: The chairman interpreted Taylor's question about promotions as a snide remark, but in all innocence Taylor was trying to figure out the company's process.

advocate.sentence_2: Martin Luther King Jr. was a tireless advocate for the rights of African-Americans in the United States.
advocate.meaning_2: noun: a person who pleads for a cause or propounds an idea
advocate.sentence_1: While the senator privately approved of gay marriage, he was unwilling to advocate for the cause in a public venue.
advocate.meaning_1: verb: speak, plead, or argue in favor of
advocate.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions, but these are the most important ones to study

consummate.sentence_2: The restoration of the ancient church was only consummated after a twenty years of labor.
consummate.meaning_2: verb: to make perfect and complete in every respect
consummate.sentence_1: Tyler was the consummate musician: he was able to play the guitar, harmonica, and the drum at the same time.
consummate.meaning_1: adjective: having or revealing supreme mastery or skill
consummate.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions, but these are the most important ones to study

quandary.meaning_1: noun: state of uncertainty or perplexity especially as requiring a choice between equally unfavorable options
quandary.sentence_1: Steve certainly is in a quandary: if he doesn't call Elaine, she will blame him for everything, but if he does call her, the evidence of where he currently is could cost him his job.

raffish.meaning_1: adjective: marked by a carefree unconventionality or disreputableness
raffish.sentence_1: The men found him raffish, but the women adored his smart clothes and casual attitude.

apprehension.sentence_1: Test day can be one of pure apprehension, as many students worry about their test scores.

renege.meaning_1: verb: fail to fulfill a promise or obligation
renege.sentence_1: We will no longer work with that vendor since it has reneged on nearly every agreement.
